Culture, biochemical assays (API identification) and PAGE
Culturing and identification according to (van Winkelhoff et al. 1985).

....trypticase soy-serumbacitracin- vancomycin (TSBV) plates (Slots 1982) for selective isolation and growth of Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans ... Identification of strictly anaerobic species was based on microscopic morphology, gram-reaction and the profile in the API 32A system. Additional tests for identification
included detection of a trypsinlike activity based on the degradation of benzoyl-DL-arginine-2-naphthylamide for the identification of P. gingivalis (van Winkelhoff
et al. 1988) and B. forsythus (Braham & Moncla 1992, Tanner et al. 1986). Identification of A.actinomycetemcomitans was based on the characteristic colony morphology (star-like inner structure) on the TSBV plate, and a positive catalase reaction upon exposure to 3% H2O2. The percentage of A.actinomycetemcomitans was calculated on the basis of the number of CFU on TSBV plates.

Helicobacter pylori was detected using a commercially availible rapid gastric urease kit (Lencomm Trade International, Poland). Samples were immediately inoculated into the rapid urease test gel. If the gel colour changed from yellow to red within 20 minutes and up to a maximum of 60 minutes then the sample was considered positive for H. pylori.
Candida species were identified using chromogenic agar (CHROMagar candida medium by Becton Dickinson), germ-tube production test and carbohydrate assimilation test
454 FLX Titanium pyrosequencing (V1 to V3 regions of the bacterial 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA)), Duplex PCR
HOMIM, Checkerboard DNA-DNA hybridization, conventional PCR, qPCR (AgP patients only)

Culture and strip technology. "Paper points samples in RTF were intensively vortexed and afterwards aliquots were cultured in media being selective for aerobe gram- negative rods (Mac Conkey agar, bioMerieux, Suisse S.A., Switzerland), staphylococci (Mannitol Salt agar, bioMerieux) and yeasts (CHROMID® Candida agar, bioMerieux). The respective microorganisms were iden- tified by routinely used methods (e.g., cell morphology, biochemistry). From the paper points, DNA was extracted and the loads of P. gingivalis, A. actinomycetemcomitans and the other bacteria associated with peri- odontal disease were analyzed by using strip technology as described before (Eick, Straube, Guentsch, Pfister, & Jentsch, 2011)."
qPCR, 16S rRNA Illumina metagenomic sequencing* (V1-V2 region)

Staphylococci were identified by clonal morphology, a positive Gram stain and catalase reaction and a negative oxidase reaction. Staphylococcal species were identified by a coagulase tube test and from the numerical profiles obtained from biochemical reactions in the API Staph system (bioMe´rieux (UK) Ltd., Basingstoke, UK), with reference to the API Staph Analytical Profile Index (bioMe´rieux).
PCR cloning analysis (newly designed Synergistetes primers 27F and 806R), further sequenced with sequencing primers 357F (22), 27F, 806R, M13(-20)F, and M13R to obtain triple coverage

Species-specific primers in the 16S rRNA coding region were selected based on sequences available in GenBank... We confirmed species specificity by sequencing at least one PCR product from a clinical sample for each primer in an ABI Prism 310 automated sequencer
Culture (isolation and identification) and checkerboard DNA probe assay
Specific monoclonal antibodies were used in an immunocytochemical assay
Roche/454 pyrosequencing of the bacterial 16S rRNA V1-V3 region
